content.description: Start with your hands in the jug towards the left of the horizontal crack and feet low down.  Pull feet up to smear and work your way right along the crack in a crouched position.  Once you get over to the right, where the lower green streaks are, mantle up and continue up the easy slabby route to top out.Hardest part about this is dealing with the sharp crystals sawing at your fingertips in the crack.  Hop down the back side, and walk down the hill.
content.location: Center of the side facing the sound.  Start jug is about 6.5 feet high.

content.description: Start at the big obvious jug.  Work your hands and feet up the horizontal features and some others around the corner.  The holds get more positive as you get higher up; feel around for the good ones.   The rocky base makes this easy climb slightly more intimidating.  Walk off the back to get down.
content.protection: Spotting is more of an art on this one.  Two crashpads would be nice because of the rocky landing.
content.location: Left most climb of on the boulder

content.description: This boulder is light colored and made of lots of sharp, sandy rock. There are some green streaks along the southwest side of the rock, which look like were cause by someone spilling paint on it.  Its about 10 to 15 feet tall.  There are smaller boulders scattered around the base, making a crash landing slightly tricky.  The tides pose less of an issue with this boulder since it is higher up on the beach, nestled into the hill.Down climbing is easy on this one by stepping off of the back side of the boulder.
